mercury_desc:
Description:
Mercury is the smallest planet in our solar system and is known for its extreme temperature variations.
mercury_size:
Size:
Diameter of about 4,880 km (3,032 miles)
mercury_distance_from_sun:
Kilometre Distance from the Sun:
Approximately 57.9 million km (36.0 million miles)
mercury_temperature:
Temperature:
Ranges from extremely hot (up to 430°C or 806°F) on its day side to extremely cold (as low as -180°C or -292°F) on its night side.
mercury_additional_info:
Additional Info:
It has a very thin atmosphere, virtually no moons, and has been visited by several space missions, including NASA's MESSENGER.
venus_desc:
Description:
Venus is often referred to as Earth's 'sister planet' due to its similar size and composition, but its extreme greenhouse effect makes it inhospitable
venus_size:
Size:
Diameter of about 12,104 km (7,521 miles)
venus_distance_from_sun:
Kilometre Distance from the Sun:
Approximately 108.2 million km (67.2 million miles)
venus_temperature:
Temperature:
It has an average surface temperature of about 465°C (869°F), hotter than Mercury despite being farther from the Sun
venus_additional_info:
Additional Info:
Venus has a thick atmosphere primarily composed of carbon dioxide, which traps heat and creates its scorching surface temperatures
earth_desc:
Description:
Earth is the only known planet to support life, with a diverse range of ecosystems and a breathable atmosphere.
earth_size:
Size:
Diameter of about 12,742 km (7,918 miles)
earth_distance_from_sun:
Kilometre Distance from the Sun:
Approximately 149.6 million km (92.9 million miles)
earth_temperature:
Temperature:
Average surface temperature around 15°C (59°F), but this can vary greatly due to climate zones
earth_additional_info:
Additional Info:
It has one natural satellite (the Moon) and is the third planet from the Sun
mars_desc:
Description:
Mars is often called the 'Red Planet' due to its reddish appearance caused by iron oxide on its surface
mars_size:
Size:
Diameter of about 6,779 km (4,212 miles)
mars_distance_from_sun:
Kilometre Distance from the Sun:
Approximately 227.9 million km (141.6 million miles)
mars_temperature:
Temperature:
Ranges from about -87°C (-125°F) to a maximum of around 20°C (68°F) near the equator during summer
mars_additional_info:
Additional Info:
Mars has polar ice caps, evidence of past liquid water flows, and several rovers and landers have explored its surface
jupiter_desc:
Description:
Jupiter is the largest planet in our solar system and is known for its immense size and powerful magnetic field
jupiter_size:
Size:
Diameter of about 139,822 km (86,881 miles)
jupiter_distance_from_sun:
Kilometre Distance from the Sun:
Approximately 778.5 million km (483.8 million miles)
jupiter_temperature:
Temperature:
Lacks a true solid surface, but its upper clouds have temperatures around -145°C (-234°F)
jupiter_additional_info:
Additional Info:
Jupiter has a prominent Great Red Spot, a massive storm, and is a gas giant composed mainly of hydrogen and helium
saturn_desc:
Description:
Saturn is recognizable for its stunning and extensive ring system
saturn_size:
Size:
Diameter of about 116,464 km (72,366 miles)
saturn_distance_from_sun:
Kilometre Distance from the Sun:
Approximately 778.5 million km (483.8 million miles)
saturn_temperature:
Temperature:
Similar to Jupiter, its upper clouds have temperatures around -178°C (-288°F)
saturn_additional_info:
Additional Info:
Saturn's rings are composed of ice and rock particles, and it has a diverse system of moons, including Titan and Enceladus
uranus_desc:
Description:
Uranus is unique for its extreme axial tilt, causing it to rotate almost perpendicular to its orbital planet
uranus_size:
Size:
Diameter of about 50,724 km (31,518 miles)
uranus_distance_from_sun:
Kilometre Distance from the Sun:
Approximately 2.87 billion km (1.78 billion miles)
uranus_temperature:
Temperature:
Very cold, with average temperatures around -224°C (-371°F)
uranus_additional_info:
Additional Info:
Uranus has a pale blue-green color due to its methane-rich atmosphere and a complex ring system
neptune_desc:
Description:
Neptune is the farthest planet from the Sun and is known for its deep blue color
neptune_size:
Size:
Diameter of about 49,244 km (30,598 miles)
neptune_distance_from_sun:
Kilometre Distance from the Sun:
Approximately 4.5 billion km (2.8 billion miles)
neptune_temperature:
Temperature:
Similar to Uranus, with average temperatures around -218°C (-360°F)
neptune_additional_info:
Additional Info:
Neptune has strong winds and the Great Dark Spot, a storm similar to Jupiter's Great Red Spot
mercury_funny_fact: Mercury's day is longer than its year! A day on Mercury takes about 59 Earth days, while its year takes only about 88 Earth days.
venus_funny_fact: Venus rotates in the opposite direction compared to most planets. It has a 'retrograde' rotation, so if you stood on Venus, the Sun would rise in the west and set in the east.
earth_funny_fact: Earth is the only planet known to have chocolate. Well, not exactly, but we do have cacao trees, and that's a start 😅!
mars_funny_fact: Mars has the largest volcano in the solar system called Olympus Mons. It's so big that if you stood on its summit, you wouldn't even realize you're on a volcano – it's that gently sloped!
jupiter_funny_fact: Jupiter's massive size is so impressive that it could fit all the other planets in the solar system inside it with room to spare – it's like the ultimate planetary party host.
saturn_funny_fact: Saturn's rings are like a cosmic hula hoop that forgot to stop spinning. Maybe Saturn just really loves to dance😃!
uranus_funny_fact: Uranus rolls on its side. If you're looking for a planet to join in on a game of planetary leapfrog, Uranus might be your best bet.
neptune_funny_fact: Neptune's winds are ridiculously fast, even though it's so far from the Sun. It's like Neptune just couldn't resist the need for speed.
